How should I track my carbon footprint?
Where does the data come from?

Cilos are the currency this app uses to measure your carbon spending. When you spend 1 Cilo (₵1) on a product, it means for that product to be made, transported, stored and disposed of, greenhouse gases equivalent to 1kg of carbon dioxide had to be emitted into the atmosphere.
In other words, a cilo is equivalent to a kilogram of carbon dioxide emissions - a carbon kilo if you will! (That\'s why it\'s pronounced with a hard "C", like "kilo")
In scientific papers, “kgCO2e” is the unit that is typically shown to measure something’s carbon footprint, but it’s the same thing.

So why give it a new name? Everything we buy has a carbon cost, as well as a financial one, and it’s important that we as individuals have the option to monitor our carbon spending in the same way we monitor our financial spending.
With that, we’d be able to find ways, specific to us, to reduce our carbon footprint in ways that have the biggest impact for the least effort.
We’d be able to set ourselves carbon budgets to help keep our carbon spending in check.
We’d be able to identify the things we buy that have the biggest carbon cost, and start thinking of those things as expensive treats which we could slowly but steadily reduce our consumption of.

And, eventually, we’d be able to choose to buy from businesses whose products have a lower carbon cost than their competitors. That would not only have the benefit of helping us reduce our own carbon footprint, but also of creating climate competition between businesses, and therefore encouraging those businesses to make genuine, verifiable improvements in their supply chains to reduce the carbon footprint of their products.
There are three main benefits of having an understanding of the carbon footprint of things you buy:
1.) It helps you reduce your individual climate impact.
2.) It encourages businesses to reduce the carbon footprint of their products.
3.) If we make the effort to understand our environmental impact and take action to reduce it, it will make it much harder for governments and people in power to avoid doing the same.
It may seem an obvious thing to say, but unless we understand our carbon footprint, it’s going to be very hard to reduce it.

Unfortunately though, it’s been almost impossible up to now for us as individuals to develop an understanding of how to reduce our climate impact beyond the generic advice such as “try and minimise flying”, “cut down on meat and dairy”, and “lower the heating”.
To be clear, that is all very good advice. But imagine you were saving up for something. Maybe you want to get married, so you need to be a bit frugal for a year or two to save up for the wedding.

Now imagine that all the information you had about how to save money was that flying, beef, and heating are all very bad… and that’s about it. When you went to the shop nothing had a price tag on it and when you bought something at checkout you had no idea what you’d just spent.
It would be tough right? You’d probably have to think about trimming the invite list.
That’s essentially what we’ve been contending with when it comes to reducing our climate impact as individuals.

Tracking your carbon footprint with Cilo will allow you to figure out exactly where your biggest carbon outlays are coming from. And you can then find ways to reduce your carbon spending that are the least effort for you.
So if your biggest carbon spending is on things you’d be happy to consume less of then you could try and slowly but steadily reduce how much of it you buy.

But if it’s a product or service that you can’t live without then maybe you can try and find a company that sells it which is genuinely and verifiably making the effort to reduce the environmental impact of its products.
If you’re tracking your carbon footprint you’ll be able to set yourself realistic goals and hopefully over time you’ll see your footprint come down.

If we’re going to tackle climate change it’s much better to continually make small improvements that we can sustain than to make big unrealistic targets that we quickly give up on. Having a true understanding of the numbers makes it much easier to do that.

Some people will argue that any carbon reductions we make as individuals are so small compared to total global emissions that it’s not worth doing. But it’s important to remember that we are a society of individuals.

The impact of one person reducing their carbon footprint by 10% is small, but the impact of 20%, 50%, or 100% of us reducing our footprint by 10% would be absolutely massive, while also being very achievable.
2.) INCENTIVISE BUSINESSES TO REDUCE THEIR CARBON FOOTPRINT:

At the moment it seems that just about every company, even those that are literally digging up the fossil fuels from the ground, is claiming that it is having a positive impact on climate change and is good for the planet generally.

The issue is that it’s very hard for us as consumers to figure out which of them are telling the truth. Again, this comes from not having enough information. Companies don’t tell us what the carbon footprint of their products are, and even if they did, we wouldn’t know if it was better than average for that type of product.
And even if we knew all that, if we didn’t know what our total carbon footprint was, we wouldn’t be able to put the saving into context.

If we track our carbon footprint though, this can all change. Businesses that claim their products are low carbon can get this verified scientifically by an independent source. Consumers would then be able to see the genuine carbon savings they could make by buying such a product, and decide if it’s worth any extra cost that might be associated.
Businesses will be able to compete as to who can provide the most low carbon product, driving a new race to the bottom line, only this time that line is zero emissions.
3.) DEMONSTRATE TO GOVERNMENTS THAT WE\'RE WILLING TO TAKE ACTION:

It is governments that have the most power to have an impact in slowing and eventually halting climate change, but they have continually proven over the last 50 years that they will not do so under their own volition.
A huge reason for that is because they are afraid that we will refuse to elect them in the future if they pursue policies that make our lives in any way more difficult than they were before.
If we demonstrate that we are willing to take action it will make it much more difficult for governments to use that as an excuse for their lack of it.

One vote every four or five years isn’t enough. Protests and marches haven’t had the desired effect. We need to keep doing both of these, but we also need to put our carbon where our mouth is and start changing things ourselves.

Although the carbon footprint of food is often portrayed as meat = bad, dairy = quite bad, and the rest = good, things are unsurprisingly a little more complicated than this. The tiers are there to give you a quick understanding of where on the spectrum of good to Amazon-rainforest-cleared-beef-bad different products lie.

Tier one products have the lowest carbon footprint and it is mostly made up of locally produced, seasonal fruit and vegetables, while tier six is at the other end of the spectrum, with the most commonly bought products in this category being beef, lamb, prawns and hard cheese.
The larger the contribution of tier 1 and tier 2 products to your overall footprint, the better.
The footprint range for each tier is as follows:
The footprint database was put together by doing a meta-analysis of existing life cycle assessment studies and articles.
For products for which no direct data could be found, we looked at their supply chains and what went into making them and made assumptions based on that to calculate a footprint estimate.

The data in its current form is far from perfect. Some estimates will be too high and others too low. But we are confident that where we have put things on the spectrum of “good” to “bad” (ie, what tier an item is in) is broadly correct.
And we are even more confident that after a month of tracking, whichever products the app tells you are the ones that are contributing the most to your total footprint will be correct.
With that being said, we know that the data is the most important thing for Cilo to get right. We want to provide data that is more accurate, more specific, and more understandable than anyone else.
That is why as Cilo grows, the amount of time and investment it puts into improving the database will grow proportionally.

Calculating and estimating carbon footprints is a very complicated process and no matter how good our methods get it will always be possible to improve them. But just because something can’t be perfected doesn’t mean it can’t still be very useful.
If you have a background in life cycle assessment and you think there’s something that could be improved in the database we’d love to hear from you! We are always trying to get better.

In order to keep global warming below 1.5°C many governments and organisations are setting targets to achieve “net zero” emissions by 2050. What this means is that any emissions they are still making by then will need to be offset by removing at least an equal amount of greenhouse gases from the atmosphere.

Despite the fact that an awareness of the need for offsets has existed for decades, no technology or methodology has ever been developed that would allow us to extract greenhouse gases from the atmosphere on a large scale. And as yet, none are close.

The issue with net zero targets is that they can give companies and governments an excuse to keep emitting as they always have done while saying their "net" emissions will reduce over time because a new technology will come along which allows them to offset them. It is important to know that no such silver bullet technology exists.

It will be far easier and cheaper for us as a society to reduce our emissions than to offset them. Some level of offsetting will be necessary because there are technologies which will be very hard to decarbonise, such as flying, and that is why continuing to develop offsetting technology is hugely important work.

But we have to have two separate targets as a society, one for reducing our emissions and one for offsetting them, so as to keep governments and companies honest. Otherwise, as happened recently, you will get oil companies promoting their oil as carbon neutral!
Most studies predict that the easiest path to net zero by 2050 would be to reduce emissions by 90% and offset the remaining 10%.

Many footprinting tools give individuals a vague notion of their footprint and then ask them to pay to offset them. We think this is more of a money grab than a helpful solution to climate change. It’s part of the reason we created Cilo.

It’s also important to know that if a company is claiming to offset your emissions by, for example, funding a renewable energy project, developing more efficient household goods, or protecting land against deforestation, while these can be very important and worthy projects to support when done right, they don’t actually lead to negative emissions - no extra CO2 is extracted from the atmosphere.
So the emissions that your actions produced remain there. As such it’s better to think of them as charitable donations rather than true offsets.
Cilo as a company is focusing on reducing emissions, not offsetting them.

Whether you decide to offset your emissions is of course entirely up to you. If you do decide to do so, our recommendation would be, firstly, not to worry about the unavoidable emissions (we all need to eat!), and then for the avoidable ones if you truly want to offset them follow the Berners-Lee Rule, which is as follows:
“To stand a hope of a legitimate offset claim, you need to show that the carbon you remove is genuinely additional to everything that needed to happen anyway without your avoidable impact.

“This rules out all the finite nature based solutions (tree-planting, soil sequestration) that humanity already needs to maximise and takes us into unproven technologies costing at present hundreds of dollars per tonne.”
We at Cilo believe individuals can play a huge role in the fight against climate change, and we wanted to create a tool that would make it easier for anyone to take action.
Our aim is to help as many people have as big an impact as possible.
If you have any thoughts on how we can do this better, issues with the app, questions, or you just want to reach out then please do. We\'d love to hear from you!
